questions: The *Eurasian* (continental) and *Pacific* plate (oceanic) converge at a *destructive* plate boundary to the *east* of Japan. The *epicentre* was 70km east of Oshika.

metadata.title: Which tectonic plates interacted to cause the earthquake?
metadata.extraTitle: Which tectonic plates interacted to cause the earthquake?

answers.text: When loosely packed, water-logged sediments at or near the ground surface lose their strength and behave like a liquid in response to strong ground shaking.
When water rises up from the mantle to the surface in response to strong ground shaking.
When building foundations lose their strength and behave like a liquid in response to strong ground shaking.

questions:
*Hospitals* were damaged so injured people couldn't be treated properly.

The biggest problem was the *nuclear* generator being shut down and the government fearing *radiation* might get into *groundwater* supplies.

Thousands of schools, offices and businesses was so badly damaged that they didn't manage to reopen for up to a *year* after the earthquake.

The government has estimated damage from the earthquake and *tsunami* at over $*200* billion making it the costliest natural *disaster* ever.

questions:
A positive from the event was that *buildings* as far away as *Tokyo* and in much of Japan swayed back-and-forth as they were designed to do which meant that collapse and further damage was avoided.

In the small coastal town of Fudai, a tsunami *wall* built in the *1970*s protected the area leaving it virtually untouched by the tsunami.

People were evacuated from a radius of 20 to *30* km around the *Fukushima* power plant.

A new tsunami wall has been created along parts of the coastline measuring *15*m in height. The previous tsunami wall which failed was only 4m in height.
